    12/23/2014
    Listed in My Neighborhood

    Really like this place:

    - Huge beer and wine selection.

    - House marinated olives (4) -- SO GOOD. They're Calvestrano olives (those giant, juicy, plump, forest green-colored ones -- my absolute fav) and they taste heavenly.

    - Meat + cheese (6 for 28) -- We combined a bunch to make a charcuterie plate. Everything was really good, the duck salami and genoa especially stood out.

    - 3 sliders (12) -- These were okay. Nothing special.

    - Chicken pot pie (13) -- More like a deconstructed pot pie. The portions were huge, and this was delicious. Probably because it had like a pound of butter and cream in it (not listed in the ingredients), and as a lactard, I did not appreciate the after-effects.

    This place is cozy, tasteful, and intimate, but gets crowded really fast. There is outdoor seating with heat lamps, but it still gets a little chilly. They don't seat your party until everyone is there.

    Tip: They don't take reservations, but you can download the NoWait app and put your name down when they open (4 PM).

    12/12/2014
    1 check-in

    Praise the Lord, hallelujah!

    I haven't gone to church in a long time, but I sing praises when it is warranted. Fat Angel makes me sing from the heart.

    This sweet, angelic spot exudes upscale lodge with a casual chic feel: marble bar, pew style booth seating and a handsome wall holding some crafted brews and carefully chosen vino. Don't mind the imposing Moosehead hanging above, Rocky and Bullwinkle totally approve.

    Fat Angel seamlessly blends fantastic wine bar food with excellent tipples. The menu is 90% alcohol (as it should be!) beers are arranged according to your taste: light, crisp, heavy, dark. Same for the wines and for those who aren't feeling both, they offer several aperitifs as well.

    It felt a little stuffy inside because of the rain, otherwise, I can imagine sitting here for hours on a warm SF night with the bay windows wide open. A crisp and zesty Picpoul was affordably priced at $8/glass. My gf loves Riesling and this one from Kabinett is a richer style with sweetness in the end. Of course, you can't go wrong with a Hefeweizen (Ayinger) or a dark stout like Double Chocolate Stout from England or a breakfast stout from Mikeller Bar (the Danes KNOW beer!)

    All this imbibing made us hungry: we devoured an excellent meat board with speck, salami and duck terrine. On the board were also FLAVORED BUTTERS like maple bacon and Philz coffee. You wouldn't be able to resist spreading these on toast! The flatbread pizzas are pleasingly light, even with rich toppings such as gorgonzola, prosciutto and grapes on it. The chicken pot pie had a really flaky crust, but I didn't taste anything special about the tarragon cream sauce.

    Hark the herald angels sing and glory to ... the genius who brought Fat Angel to San Francisco. Let's say Amen to that!

    Listed in 2014 Reviews, San Francisco Fog City

    This place is awesome.

    Extensive beer list (100+ super local beers) - check
    Friendly elk greeting from the wall - check
    (optional) Christmas tree with Polaroid pictures of the patrons - check

    The super friendly gals working at the bar will seat you quickly in this intimite but yet lively place. You might be surprised that the beer/wine selection takes about 90% of the menu but this is a wine bar after all. However, also come here for the food as it's delicious!

    The FLATBREAD PIZZA comes in various styles (Firebrand sourdough baguette and whole grain mustard with chorizo, duck salami, genoa, pheasant terrine, speck, or soppressata, $5-$28) and is worth every penny - most delicious topped sourdough I've had in a while, and super crispy.

    The SOURDOUGH & BUTTER ($5) satisfies in a special kinda way - have you tried Philz Cofffee butter or Maple Bacon butter? I bet you haven't. Go order.

    Finally, the CHICKEN POT PIE (roast chicken, carrots, sherry, tarragon, $13) was creamy and had a sweet hint to it. Marvelous.

    Fat Angel - a pleasant surprise in the lower Fillmore area. Stay where you are, angel. I'll be back.

    12/1/2014

    fat angel is like everything i want in a local establishment - lots of cheese, homemade bread, fresh local salads, artisan bar bites (sliders, flatbreads and the like), charcuterie, an extensive beer/cider/wine list and taxidermy on the wall. i absolutely love this place!

    yes, it's bordering the sketchiness that is the western addition but its tucked away so you almost forget where you are.

    the wait is sometimes a little too long to justify, but if you catch them at a good time you'll be happy you stopped by.

    besides the flavored butters, charcuterie and cheese offerings - the kale salad, sliders and gorgonzola flatbread are absolutely delicious. you've gotta order those!

    Listed in Eat and Explore SF

    Stopped by here for some quick drinks before a concert at the Fillmore.

    Didn't eat anything here, but loved the organic and fairytale-feel of the atmosphere! Ambiance was magical with their candlelight lighting and delicious aromas from the kitchen.

    The spot is quite small with a narrow bar section and closely-arranged tables for diners. This would be a perfect spot for date night or a toned-down girls night with friends.

    I do want to give a HUGE 5 stars to the bartender and (seemingly) host who's name is Derek. He's an absolute top-notch bartender here focused on providing high-quality service to ALL customers. He really helped me find the beer that I wanted by letting me taste beer after beer on their tap list--props to you good sir! I also work in the hospitality industry, so I KNOW A GREAT BARTENDER/SERVER when I interact with one.

    I'd love to come here for the food next time, and considering the incredible service my friends and I had with Derek, there will be a round 2.

    Had my last meal here before I headed off to Taiwan!

    My boyfriend, my mom and I arrived around 5 PM and we were the only ones there, which was nice because we had the undivided attention of the servers. We ordered the sausage flatbread, the endive salad and the smoked trout with greens. My mom also ordered a coffee which was freshly made, one cup at a time. It was delicious!

    The food didn't take long to come out but at first we thought they had forgotten to give us the additional chicken we ordered for the endive salad. They didn't forget, they just brought it out later so no problem there. I really enjoyed the sausage flatbread because the bread was really thin and the arugula went really well with the sausage and tomato. I think I ate about half of it by myself lol. The endive salad was pretty good but I wouldn't recommend ordering the chicken as a side, because it was pretty dry. The trout on the other hand was very tasty, and the greens were delicious.

    We didn't order any drinks (aside from the coffee), so I can't comment on that except for the fact that 75% of the menu encompassed libations which was interesting. It also can be a bit difficult to flag down your server once it gets busy; my mom needed another coffee and she had to go up to the bar to let them know.

    Fat Angel might want to consider a diaper change... the service as of late just stinks!

    Yes, I love…     Fat Angel might want to consider a diaper change... the service as of late just stinks!

    Yes, I love their food and wine. What's not to love about their amazing charcuterie plates, honey butter + bags of fresh bread? Not to mention all of the wonderful wine and beer on tap. And yes, it's warm and cozy inside.

    I used to have friends who lived in the area and we spent quite a bit of time at Fat Angel. The two gentleman (brothers?) who own the place were always there, super friendly and accommodating. That was about 8-9 months ago. Warm fuzzy memories indeed, hence the 5-star review.

    Had a Fat Angel craving last night and decided to head up there. It was busy, but not intimidatingly so. There was a table available (or so we thought) so the bus boy offered to let us sit down. As soon as we did so, one of the gals who works there yelled at us and said "Hey guys, there's a wait list for tables." My bad! Let's put our name on the list, no problem.

    Another table opens up, so the same busser offers to let us sit down again. "Are you sure?" I ask. He nods his head. Again, we get yelled at like a kid throwing rocks on the playground by the same waitress. Who gets the table instead? A group of four who's already been served and is seated comfortably at the bar. WTF? By the time we move across the room, the four seats at the bar are claimed by two couples waiting for a table.

    Yet another table opens up and the other waitress gives it to a group who just happens to walk in the door and make eye contact with her. Do they get yelled at and told to move? Nope. We get a shrug and told "You guys are next, for sure". Mind you, there's only 3 tables inside that can accommodate a group of 4 or more, so the wait was just doubled. By that time, we decided to go elsewhere. Not worth it.

    This was the second time that I've been here over the last few weeks where the owners aren't present and the same two frazzled (sometimes nice, sometimes not-so-nice) women are stuck bar tending as well as waiting on all the tables. It's not a big place, but by the way they act, you'd think they were managing a restaurant twice the size. Call me crazy and demanding, but going out to enjoy wine and a cheese plate shouldn't be so stressful.

    I would put the entire experience into the same category as Sam Wo's: yelp.com/biz/sam-wo-rest… - good food, but watch out for the people who work there!     Read more

    ROTD 8/12/2014

    Crowded bar/restaurant close to Fillmore/Japantown

    With the dim red heat lamps outside the entrance, the place always looked like a party spot whenever I stop by. When I finally had a chance to visit, it turns out the decor inside is quite interesting as well, with a wood/nature/animal theme. There is a large selection of beer, wine, and cocktails--the tall poppy I got was definitely nice, with a distinct flavor that I haven't tasted before.

    The food items are also equally satisfying, though not cheap--the cheese blocks and the salami items are savory, and aromatic. Also, everyone pretty much orders the mac&cheese, which is cooked just right with a crusty layer of cheese near the center of the plate. mmmmm

    The price is definitely on the mid-to-high range, so be aware before stepping in.

    Overall, a pretty good place to visit once in a while with friends

    Listed in Wine-O!, Pizza, Pizza!

    I love to wine and dine with Fat Angel!

    Their flatbread pizza with gorgonzola, walnut, prosciutto and topped with roasted grapes, is deliciously amazing! Pair it with their grand selections of fine wine, such as their Manto Negro/Callet from Spain, which had hints of cocoa, toffee and cherry blend, then the meal would be splendidly perfect to the palate!

    Their freshly baked Chicken Pot Pie that is served piping hot from the oven, is surely homely and that crisp and flaky crust, is comfort to the soul!

    They serve up beer as well, just in case you prefer not to dine over wine!

    I simply can't ask for better company to pair a meal and wine over with, than with Fat Angel!

    12 check-ins
    Listed in My Favorite Restaurants

    I figured I should write a more comprehensive review for fat angel considering it's one if my favorite spots. This place is what a gastro pub should be. Great beer and wine selection and delicious consistent food. It is quite small and very popular. The combination of small and popular is actually the major drawback of the place. They do not take reservations so wait times can be upwards of 1-2 hours at times if you want a table for dinner. You can put your name on a list and they will text you when a table becomes available, but this system may not be ideal for some. Also considering that some people order food and then sit at tables for hours drinking after dinner makes it difficult for the staff to accurately predict wait times. Also since they have outdoor seating, weather becomes a variable in that on nice days their seating capacity almost doubles.

    The staff is always very friendly and do their best to accommodate given the limitations listed above. They are understandably in a tricky situation and there is no great way to make everyone happy!

    When you walk in there is a chalkboard that lists the beer and wine on tap. This is an ever changing selection which is great. Occasionally they run out of beers and the selection of tap beer can be limited. They make up for this with a huge selection of bottled beers listed by type in their menu.

    Just about everything on the food menu is awesome. My favorites are the maple bacon butter, kale salad with chicken, all of the flat breads, and the sliders. These all seem to pair perfectly with the beer.

    This place is located right across the street from a friends apartment, so he recommended us to go here! It was a Saturday night around 10ish when we got there. Inside was still relatively crowded but we were still able to get seating after a short wait.

    We ordered the spicy Mac & cheese ($13) which was just as good as all the other Yelpers claimed! (Yay I'm joining the bandwagon) I do think it's a bit pricey, the plate is rather small but it is pretty dense so it will fill you up especially if you're not sharing. The sliders ($13) were also really good!! Definitely recommend that. We also got a cheese plate..it's served with bread and jelly.

    For drinks, I can only speak for myself. I got the Sauvignon blanc (2013) and it tasted like crap. I couldn't finish it :( and I hate wasting alcohol.

    The ambience of this place is casual! Kinda dark inside. The decorations are cool. The bathroom is nice and clean too!! There's even decorations inside. This is a plus for me, somebody who has a small bladder and spends much of their time running to the bathroom. :)

    Overall great experience, just pricey. $80+ for 3 people.

My friend had the trout and he said it was the best trout he ever had - well, to be honest I think it was the first time he had trout. If you are into trying different beers I suggest that you visit this place. The service is spectacular and the atmosphere is nice. We enjoyed our visit a lot. We hope to be able to go back soon.

    6/6/2014 Previous review
    Yesterday I planned to have a sort of foodie/gastropub adventure in SF with my girlfriend. Fat Angel… Yesterday I planned to have a sort of foodie/gastropub adventure in SF with my girlfriend. Fat Angel was the first place on a little list I made up of evening stops. Coming here effectively ruined the rest of my night in the best way possible.

    Good.
    -The selection here is amazing. I find that with many places with a huge beer list they stuff in things that any dude can pick up at Bevmo. While this isn't a huge deal because there's almost always going to be something new..it does take some of the novelty out of it. I enjoy coming to a bar and looking down the list and trying new things I couldn't get from the store, and that is the case here. They have a huge selection of beers that I have never seen and its all broken down into what type it is. I am a huge fan of Sour beers and this place has a selection of about 15 with only a handful being something I have seen before, that alone had me sold on the place.

    -The service I had here was amazing. Derek was the name of our waiter/host and his service was some of the best I have ever had. I admit that usually when a waiter sits down at a table to take your order I feel a bit overwhelmed. I get that its to get on your level and be personable but it always feels like the server is trying to Bro-out with you and i just want them to piss off after that. But here I felt like he sat down because there was a lot to tell me about the beers. I didn't feel rushed or overwhelmed, that surprised me quite a bit. We asked the question about how do you keep all the beers in such a tiny place so he even went so far as to show us the storage room and explain about it. Derek had extensive knowledge about every single thing on the menu and went out of his way to give tasters when I was unsure on things. This was service at its finest and I had one reason to come back here it was because of this.

    - Decor had a nice vibe to it. The bar looks like a refurbished western saloon style. They also had a stuffed animal head and a chandelier which is usually signs for the tackiest decor ever but with the bar backdrop it worked quite well. I guess what im trying to say is its not in your face so even if you do find it tacky its not staring you down. The rest of the place has a nice plain look to it, being a tiny location it pays off not to shove more crap into the seating area.

    - They have a very skim menu when it comes to food but it does seek to impress. They have what seems to be rotational cheeses and meats that are all top quality AND finally a place that doesn't skimp on how much they serve! I initially stuck with this until I gave in and decided to stay. Next up I ordered the Spicy Mac which was amazing as promised. They do Gastropub right here, no need for an overly abundant food menu just the basics that work well. Drunk people tend to get confused with given too many option. I would also like to add that the prices match the food given, so I was never underwhelmed.

    Bad
    - Its a tiny place and I can't stress that enough. We got there right when it opened and had plenty of room but once it gets to around 6 or 7 it starts to fill up quite a bit. It becomes quite packed in once you get some parties standing and drinking near the bar. Then you start to realize how close the tables are together and how much you know about the people sitting next to you after hearing their conversation for the last hour. This is not a fixable issue its just more of a minor annoyance you need to deal with to enjoy such a great place.

    - The care and attention from the staff is great but you can see when it becomes a hindrance. I am trying to word this in a way that makes it known I don't want the staffs style to change, but its something I have seen hit on in other reviews. You have the two camps of people who go here because it does have a large beer section. You have those that are interested in this stuff and want to know more and who dont mind waiting because you know that you will get the same level of great service. Then you have the people who come here because they have a lot to drink and really anything will do. Its this group of people that mind quite a bit.

    -My girlfriend is Gluten Intolerant and aside from Mead or Wine this place doesn't cater to that really. Its a minor thing as she loves wine but the addition of a tolerable Gluten free beer might be nice. (And please let it not be Greens, that beers a joke)

    Overall.
    I never say this about any place in SF because it is so far away but I do plan on coming back here for sure. Everything about this place from the top down is worth it. The complimentary wine on the way out topped off an already amazing experience and effectively ruined every other place I went to after that. I have a nasty habit of getting stuck at the first place i go to on food/drink adventures and this one was completely justified.
    Thank you for the great time

    Dog?- Very dog friendly in the front patio.
    Gluten? Knowledge of GF items but nothing to really offe     Read more

    Came in on a Friday night around 8:30 and had to wait about 30 min for a spot. They'll take your phone number and text you when it's ready so you don't have to physically be there.

    We ended up getting seated at the bar, which was fine. But it took about 20 min until someone acknowledged us (only about 3 ladies were working). We were able to sample some of the wines before we decided on what glass to take. The server was super friendly and knowledgable. I noticed it's the same price to drink wines by the glass versus buying a bottle, so it allows you to try multiple kinds! And the pours are generous!

    For food we ordered the wild mushroom flatbread with truffle oil and a salad and added rotisserie chicken for $3.

    The endive salad was a hefty portion! I do wish there was a bit more chicken throughout, but it was tender and flavorful. I enjoyed that it wasn't overly done, but bf found it to be too sweet for his tastes.

    The flatbread was delicious as well! Almost a cracker crust with bits of pecorino cheese.

    Prices are a tad bit high for what you get, but I think you're paying more for the location and vibe.

    What a neighborhood gem. Like a good Yelper, I observed from Yelp friends' check-ins that Fat Angel was/is the place to go. I've walked by it many times especially on Saturdays when the Fillmore Farmers' Market takes place. Now I know what all the rage is about. It's low key, the food is good, and the patrons are locals. Not that this place needs another glowing review (as there are many already), but here are my two cents.

    I walked in promptly at 7 on Sunday night to join some friends for dinner. They've been here before and agreed to my recommendation. Clearly, they were also happy former patrons. One of my friends noted their wine selection is among the best, and I saw that as well. They have an extensive wine menu... but I wasn't there for wine. I was there for other libations. So, I ordered the Pimm's Cup: lemonade, Pimms #1, and cava. This came with plenty of ice (which I personally enjoy). Very refreshing, and had just enough bite and alcoholic "zing!" for a Sunday evening.

    We decided to share a charcuterie platter which was, no doubt, a fantastic idea. The prime selection of meats and cheeses came with spiced and candied nuts, various jams, and mustard. Loved it. Oh, and duh! It came with copious amounts of bread. How could I forget THAT?!

    We also shared the endive, apple, candied walnuts, and gorgonzola salad with roasted chicken shreds (+$3). This was a delicious and heaping amount of greens and fruit, and very much needed with all the meats and cheeses we were consuming! And well, did I mention we needed salad to also balance the very decadent mac & cheese? That mac & cheese: I want to just lift that hot plate and put it right onto my face. It consisted of three cheeses: gruyere, cheddar, and parmigiano-reggiano. The bread crumbs on top and the spice of cayenne pepper really made this mac & cheese distinctive from others. Granted, I've had bread crumbs on mac & cheese before, but this was toasted to perfection and the spice cut through the creamy richness of the dish.

    The service: solid. The servers were friendly and quite personable. While my friends and I were very much engaged in deep conversations (at one point we were talking about economics... I mean, who does that on a Sunday night?... [We do.]), I noticed how efficient and attentive the service was. I'm glad I was able to experience a meal at Fat Angel. I intend to come back for dinner or perhaps a casual drink on their petite patio out front. Give this spot a try. It's heavenly! (Womp. Womp.)

    Second time here and it's still great. Definitely a small place for a small group of people. The focus here is mostly on the libations part... Obviously from the name :) The food is pretty good though (just a bit on the expensive side for what you get). Even though it is pricey, it's worth it to get a couple of the small plates (especially the meats and cheeses) since it pairs really well with the drinks. Also, keep in mind, the menu changes every now and then, so it's kind of a different experience (at least from the two times I've been there).

    They have a bunch of beers on tap and a vast selection of wine and bottled beer. They have everything from cheap to like... almost $72 for a bottle of beer (didn't really pay attention to the wines because we weren't really there for wine). The second time I've went here, we had just gotten out of a very beery brunch at 21st Amendment, so we didn't really order much alcohol; only Drake's 2013 Jolly Rodger Imperial American Black Ale (how awesome is that name). It was the last bottle though... but damn that was good. Highly recommend it... if you can find it somewhere else XD

    We ordered the lemon caper sage butter (maple bacon is better), sliders (meh), mac and cheese (yum!), and a meat plate with salchichon, two slices of duck liver pâté ('cause we're so fancy), speck, duck salami, and truffled wild boar. The meat plate was definitely better this time around (don't remember the last one we had), and you get a brown bag filled to the brim with bread (which is crazy yummy). The meat plate also comes with a great mustard which brings it all together. Would definitely avoid the sliders though... came out a little soggy... and honestly not very unique/flavorful. The mac and cheese comes in a tiny little cast iron with these awesome breadcrumbs on top.

    I like this place for the random selection and the chill atmosphere. Luckily the second time we went, it was waaaaaaaaaaay quieter (we were the only ones in the resturant, minus some of the tables outside) and it was great to hang out with a couple friends. It did start to fill up a little bit by 6 pm (halfish full) but by then we were pretty sated and happy.

    Would come back, would recommend, but really the attraction here is the drink! The staff is super friendly too. Definitely has hipster written all over it :D

    Now *this* is a gastropub... high-quality libations AND food. It's unassumingly cool yet cozy: there's something about their old-school chalkboard menus and fabulous chandeliers that speaks to me -- even that big ol' deer head mounted on the wall seems charming in this space.     The microbrews are awesome; the flatbreads are tasty; and the salads are HUGE. Outdoor seating is lovely during the warmer days, but the tiny little inside (especially the bar) is really a great place to sit and eat a bite, too. They've got a fabulous selection of wine (you gotta love a place that has wine on tap) if you're in a vino kinda mood, which very well might strike given the romantic atmosphere.

    Overall, a great little spot to sit, sip, and simply enjoy. I'll be back!

From the business

Learn more about Fat Angel , Opens a popup

Specialties

30 wines by the glass from around the globe, 6 California draft wines & 9 artisan draft beers, and a revolving, eclectic 100+ bottle beer menu.  Our food is American comfort with mac n' cheese, chicken pot pie, beef sliders, huge salads and flatbreads.  Our ever revolving meat, cheese, and butter boards are not to be missed.

History

Established in 2010.

Fat Angel was born out of a passion for The Fillmore District. We are a casual wine bar and cafe that serves comforting food and drink to the community. We offer a handpicked, eclectic mix of wine and beer that spans the globe, focusing on regions and producers that offer exceptional value and quality. Our restaurant was built with reclaimed, repurposed, and recycled materials from around San Francisco. This creates an intimate, old world environment, perfect for hanging out with friends, drinking a glass of wine, and eating a nourishing meal. Fat Angel's mission is to become The Fillmore's benchmark in food, service, price, & atmosphere.
